42. You should also renounce Minium and Spanish green,
And Orpiment, poisonous by nature.
I advise you to clean your Brushes well,
or keep some for clear blue Fabric
or Skies, and moreover, if you can do so,
be sure to provide yourself over time
with pure colors and learn to keep them ready,
as one who holds art in esteem and honors it.
right-middleAvoiding Minium, Spanish green, and Orpiment.

43. The smalts must be well absorbed.
To achieve this, some prick very dense holes
In their panels with needles.
Others cover their work with some rough paper,
which they leave there to draw out
the oil, and some others paint
with Poppyseed oil, while others
use Oil prepared according to their own experience.
right-middleSmalts must be absorbed, to discolor less.

ab.b: End of Painting well, or the Application of Colors.

Chapter XIII. Origin, Nature, Power and Effects of Colors.
The Thirteenth Chapter.

div.ab:
1. In the beginning, as all creatures
receive from their highly praised Creator
origin, shape, and being,
all visible that the eye can encompass,
how numerous diverse and how strange in nature–
all of them have received their color
from this most artful Sculptor and Painter.
How can the origin of the Colors be more abundant?
right-middleAll have their colors from God.

2. But when darkness was in the depths,
or, as the poets suppose about Chaos,
before things were ordered,
when the Sky was devoured by Darkness
all together and upside down,
the colors, with their various names,
did not yet exist, or, if they did,
were fully hidden, still to be revealed.
right-middleColors emerged with the creation of the world.

3. Surely, everywhere the Darkness
can dominate or defeat the Light in battle,
no colors are prevented, but the sight
is neither strong nor keen enough
to cut through the thick black darkness.
right-middleDarkness prevailed and prevented the colors from being distinguished.
